Fig. 1 (A) XRD patterns of the catalysts: (a) Co3O4/eggshell-GR, (b) Co3O4/eggshell-IM, (c) Co3O4/eggshell-DP, (d) Co3O4/CaCO3, and (e) Co3O4; (B) enlargement of XRD patterns at 30–45° of (A). Fig 1 Fig. 2 FT-IR spectra of the catalysts: (a) Co3O4/eggshell-GR, (b) Co3O4/eggshell-IM, (c) Co3O4/eggshell-DP, (d) Co3O4/CaCO3, and (e) Co3O4. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (HR)-TEM images of the samples: (a) eggshell, (b) Co3O4/eggshell-GR, (c) Co3O4/eggshell-IM, (d) and (d’) Co3O4/eggshell-DP. Fig 3 Fig. 4 HADDF-STEM and EDX mapping images of the Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst. Fig 4 Fig. 5 H2-TPR profiles of the samples: (a) Co3O4/eggshell-GR, (b) Co3O4/eggshell-IM, (c) Co3O4/eggshell-DP, (d) Co3O4, and (e) eggshell. Co3O4 shows excellent catalytic activity for N2O decomposition, in which it is urgently needed to develop novel efficient catalysts/supports with cheap and environmentally-friendly properties. Herein, Co3O4 nanoparticles decorated eggshell catalysts (Co3O4/eggshell-GR, Co3O4/eggshell-IM, and Co3O4/eggshell-DP) were prepared using simple grinding, impregnation, and deposition-precipitation methods, where waste eggshells were used as an effective support and reaction-promoter. The results indicated that the preparation methods significantly influenced the catalytic activity of Co3O4/eggshell catalysts; the highest activity was obtained over the Co3O4/eggshell-DP. The activity of Co3O4/eggshell-DP was comparable to that of pure Co3O4. More importantly, its specific activity was about 7.3 times that of Co3O4 at 400 °C. The examined Co3O4/eggshell-DP also displayed outstanding stability and anti-poisoning property in NO, O2, and/or H2O-containing atmospheres. It was also verified that the excellent activity of Co3O4/eggshell-DP correlated with the unique structure of the eggshell and the close incorporation between CaCO3 and Co3O4. The Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst owned abundant Co3O4 nanoparticles, more Co3+ species, and excellent redox performance, promoting the conversion of N2O at a lower temperature. The presence of abundant surface basic sites and a larger amount of oxygen vacancies also facilitated the catalytic efficiency of Co3O4/eggshell-DP. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Co3O4 Eggshell N2O Catalytic decomposition CaCO3 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrous oxide (N2O) is a commonly known atmospheric pollutant. It is an inevitable by-product of the industrial chemical processes, combustion of fossil fuel and biomass, and vehicle exhaust [1]. It is not only a highly potent greenhouse gas, and its global warming potential is 310 times higher than that of CO2, and it also contributes to the degradation of the stratospheric ozone layer [2]. Previous studies have hypothesized that N2O would be the dominant ozone-depleting substance in the 21st century [3]. Furthermore, with an annual increase in the overall atmospheric N2O levels, these are expected to reach twice the current levels by 2050 [4]. Thus, there is an urgent need to identify ways to eliminate N2O emissions for environmental protection. Several post-treatment technologies have been developed to eliminate N2O. These include direct catalytic decomposition of N2O (deN2O), considered the most viable due to its simplicity, high efficiency, and absence of secondary pollution [2]. Consequently, various catalytic systems, such as noble metals (bare and supported) [1,5,6], metal oxides (single and composite) [7–9], perovskites [10,11], hydrotalcites [12,13], hexaferrites [14,15], Co-hydroxyapatite [16], spinels [17–19], and ion-exchanged zeolites [20–22] have been investigated for deN2O. One of the most promising catalytic systems for deN2O is Co3O4 spinel, which has been shown to show enhanced activity by surface and bulk doping modification as well as by the formation of catalytically active interfaces. Thus, doping of Co3O4 with a small amount of alkali metals [17], alkali earth metals [23,24], nonmetals [8], and other oxides like yttrium [19], gadolinium [25], and cerium [4] could significantly improve its catalytic activity towards deN2O. Kim et al. [17] showed that the deN2O activity of the K/Co3O4 catalyst was significantly higher than that of Co3O4. The enhanced activity of the K/Co3O4 catalyst was attributed to the increase in surface area and redox ability. Zhang et al. [23] reported that the addition of Ca into Co3O4 resulted in excellent catalytic activity for deN2O compared to Co3O4 and was primarily due to an increased amount of surface oxygen and better reducibility. A study by Xiong et al. [25] reported superior deN2O activity of the Gd2O3-Co3O4 catalyst in comparison to that of Co3O4, which was attributed to a large specific surface area, plentiful active sites and weak Co-O bond. Based on the results of our previous studies [19], the introduction of Y2O3 into Co3O4 was found to result in improved catalytic activity. The interaction between Y2O3 and Co3O4 at the interface of Y2O3/Co3O4 facilitated electron donation of Co2+ and accelerated O2 desorption, which endowed Y2O3-Co3O4 with superior catalytic activity for deN2O. Despite the enhanced catalytic activity provided by these doped and modified Co3O4 catalysts compared to that of Co3O4 for deN2O, some issues still exist. First, these catalysts mainly contain bulk Co3O4 with Co3O4 as an active component. The Co3O4 active component gets sintered during calcining and use, resulting in unfavorable effects on catalytic deN2O [25]. Second, specific activities, i.e., the utilization rates of the Co3O4 active component of these catalysts, are relatively low, because activation of the absorbed N2O molecules occurs at the gas-solid interface [26]. Third, most of these catalysts are inhibited by gaseous impurities, such as H2O, O2 and/or NO in the deN2O reaction [27]. Additionally, these Co3O4-based catalysts are not suitable for large-scale practical applications due to the high price of cobalt [28]. Immobilizing Co3O4 nanoparticles on solid supports to develop advanced materials is an effective approach to solving the aforementioned problems [29]. There are many reports concerning the deposition of Co3O4 on supports such as CeO2 [18], ZrO2 [26], g-C3N4 [27], and CaCO3 [30]. However, a good design and efficient preparation of practical supported Co3O4-based catalysts for catalytic deN2O are essential. There is also a real need for cost-efficient, environment-friendly, and easy-to-use supports. Chicken eggshell is an inexpensive and readily available biomaterial consisting of three layers from the inside outwards: the mammillary layer, calcium carbonate (CaCO3) layer, and cuticle layer. It is estimated that there are almost 7000–17,000 pore canals between the outermost and middle layers for exchanging matter [31,32]. Eggshell is primarily made of CaCO3, ca. 96 wt.%, with small amounts of other inorganic components (mainly magnesium carbonate and calcium phosphate) and organic components (mainly proteins and polysaccharides) [33]. As noted earlier, Ca was reported to have a big impact on the deN2O activity when used as an additive of the Co3O4 catalyst [24]. CaCO3 was reported to be an efficient support, and Co3O4/CaCO3 catalyst showed quite stable and high activity in the deN2O reaction [30]. Considering its intrinsic porous structure, firm and hierarchical architecture, and especially high Ca or CaCO3 content, it was thought that eggshell would be a good candidate for preparing practical supported Co3O4-based catalysts for catalytic deN2O and that immobilizing Co3O4 nanoparticles on eggshell would be beneficial for mitigating the problems of the Co3O4-based catalysts in deN2O. Eggshell is usually discarded, causing environmental pollution and wastage of this valuable resource [31]. Recently, tremendous efforts have been made to use eggshells in electrodes, tissue scaffolds, and bone tissue repair [34–39]. Additionally, eggshells have been used as economic and environmental-friendly support to prepare heterogeneous catalysts for benzene oxidation [40], biodiesel production [33], and hydrogen production [31]. However, there are few reports on using eggshells as support to prepare catalysts for catalytic deN2O. Further, immobilizing Co3O4 nanoparticles on eggshells for deN2O is not reported. In this study, a more efficient and practical supported Co3O4-based catalyst for catalytic deN2O was developed by preparing novel eggshell-templated Co3O4/CaCO3 catalysts. This research group synthesized these catalysts using grinding, impregnation, and deposition-precipitation methods. The Co3O4/eggshell catalyst prepared by the deposition-precipitation method showed the best deN2O activity. It exhibited a much higher specific activity, a better resistance to impurity gasses, and greater stability than the Co3O4 catalyst. Various analytical tools were employed to characterize the physic-chemical properties of the samples. The relations of these properties to the catalytic activity have been discussed in detail in the manuscript. The facile synthesis, available industrial mass production, environmental-friendliness, low cost, and outstanding activity are expected to make the Co3O4/eggshell catalyst widely applied in practical catalytic deN2O. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and agents Waste chicken eggshells were obtained from the student canteen at Shanxi University in China. The eggshells were thoroughly rinsed with distilled water and then dried at 120 °C overnight. Subsequently, they were calcined in air at 500 °C for 3 h. The resulting calcined eggshells were ground and sifted by 200-mesh sieve to obtain eggshell powder. The cobalt nitrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O) and calcium nitrate (Ca(NO3)2·4H2O) used in the experiment were purchased from Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent Factory (China). The sodium carbonate (Na2CO3) was obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All reagents were of analytical grade and without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts In this study, Co3O4/eggshell catalysts were prepared using grinding, impregnation, and deposition-precipitation methods. The theoretical content of Co3O4 in the resulting catalysts was calculated to be ca. 20 wt.%. Further details of the preparation process are provided below. 2.2.1 Preparation of Co3O4/eggshell-GR A precursor mixture was obtained by grinding eggshell powder (5 g) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (4.5322 g) at room temperature. The resulting mixture was then calcined in static air at 450 °C for 3 h, and the catalyst was named Co3O4/eggshell-GR. 2.2.2 Preparation of Co3O4/eggshell-IM Co(NO3)2·6H2O (4.5322 g) was dissolved in distilled water (50 mL) to give a solution. Eggshell powder (5 g) was added to the solution and stirred for 12 h. The mixture was heated gradually to 80 °C with stirring to evaporate the water and a slurry was formed. The resulting slurry was then dried in an oven at (50 °C, 12 h) and calcined in static air at (450 °C, 3 h). The resulting catalyst was designated as Co3O4/eggshell-IM. 2.2.3 Preparation of Co3O4/eggshell-DP Co(NO3)2·6H2O (4.5322 g) was dissolved in distilled water (50 mL) at 40 °C, and eggshell powder (5 g) was dispersed in the above solution with vigorous stirring. A solution of Na2CO3 (1 M) was then added drop-wise until the final pH reached ca. 9. The mixture was stirred for 3 h at the same temperature. The resulting solid was filtered, washed with deionized water until the pH reached 7, dried at 120 °C overnight, and calcined at 450 °C in static air for 3 h. The resulting catalyst was abbreviated as Co3O4/eggshell-DP. For comparisons, some other CaCO3 support and Co3O4/CaCO3 catalyst were prepared using the same deposition-precipitation method as described above. Additionally, Co3O4 catalyst was prepared via precipitation with Na2CO3 as a precipitant using our developed method [26], with the only difference being the calcination process temperature (450 °C) and time (3 h). 2.3 Characterization The prepared samples were subjected to various measurements such as XRD, FT-IR, BET, (HR)-TEM, HADDF-STEM, H2-TPR, XPS, CO2-TPD, conductivity test, ICP-AES, and EPR. These measurements were similar to those described in our previous papers [27] and can be found in more detail in the Supporting Information file. 2.4 Catalytic tests The 300 mg catalyst was loaded into a quartz reactor (4 mm i.d.) and placed in a fixed-bed flow microreactor at 0.1 MPa. The gas mixtures containing 1000 ppm N2O with or without 3 vol.% O2, 3.3 vol.% H2O, and/or 200 ppm NO, Ar balance were continuously flowing at a flow rate of 50 mL·min−1 and the gas hour space velocity was 10,000 h−1 (GHSV). To obtain reaction gas with humidity, the feed gas was passed through a water bubbler. The water vapor content can be controlled by adjusting the temperature of the water bubbler. To determine the conversion rate of N2O, a gas chromatograph equipped with TCD (model: Agilent 7890B; columns: PoraPLOT Q and HP-MOLESIEVE) is used for online analysis of reactants and catalytic products. The conversion rate of N2O can be calculated using the given formula: (I) N 2 O conversion ( % ) = [ N 2 O ] in − [ N 2 O ] out [ N 2 O ] in × 100 ( % ) where [N2O]in and [N2O]out represent initial and postreaction concentrations of N2O molecules, respectively. The equation for specific activity calculation is provided in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts 3.1.1 XRD analysis The XRD patterns of pure Co3O4, Co3O4/CaCO3, and Co3O4/eggshell catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 1 (A). The diffractogram patterns of pure eggshell and CaCO3 supports are also displayed in Fig. S1 for reference. For the CaCO3 support, a number of strong characteristic peaks of CaCO3 (JCPDS PDF#05–0586) were observed at 2θ = 23.0, 29.4, 31.4, 35.2, 39.4, 43.1, 47.5, 48.5, 56.6, 57.4, and 60.6° [33]. The XRD pattern of eggshell was similar to CaCO3, confirming the main component of eggshell was CaCO3. Compared with the eggshell and CaCO3 supports as well as the Co3O4 catalyst, the Co3O4/CaCO3 and Co3O4/eggshell catalysts showed an obvious Co3O4 reflection due to the Co3O4 (311) 2θ = 38.6° peak (JCPDS PDF#42–1467) [19] without any shift. No other extra diffraction peaks were observed on these catalysts. A clear indication that all of these catalysts had the spinel structure of Co3O4. Ca primarily existed as CaCO3; It did not form a new phase with Co species and was not incorporated into Co3O4 spinel crystal lattice by substituting Co sites in the samples. Remarkably, the diffraction peak intensity of Co3O4 (311) 2θ = 38.6° in the XRD of Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst increased compared with Co3O4/eggshell samples (as shown in Fig. 1(B)). This indicated the formation of more abundant Co3O4 nanoparticles and the close incorporation between Co3O4 nanoparticles and eggshell support [41]. Table 1 shows the crystal size of CaCO3 and Co3O4 calculated by the Scherrer equation. The average size of Co3O4 crystallites for Co3O4/CaCO3 and Co3O4/eggshell samples ranged from 13 to 18 nm, smaller than that of Co3O4 (27.8 nm). Thus, the presence of CaCO3 and eggshell could reduce the crystal size of Co3O4 in the Co3O4/CaCO3 and Co3O4/eggshell catalysts. 3.1.2 FT-IR analysis FT-IR spectra of the samples were analyzed to determine the presence of functional groups. Fig. S2 displays the FT-IR spectra of pure eggshell, and CaCO3 supports in KBr pellets. Eight prominent characteristic absorption bands appeared for the two supports without any offset. Taking CaCO3 support as a reference, the data analysis revealed a band at 3494 cm−1, attributed to the OH group stretching vibration due to the adsorption water [33]. The bands centered at 2976, 2875, and 1801 cm−1 were recognized as the stretching vibration of C=O bonds in the carbonates [33]. The band at position 2517 cm−1 was characteristic of CaCO3 [33]. The most intense infrared absorption band located at 1421 cm−1 corresponded to the CO stretching mode of CaCO3 [41]. The last two bands at 876 and 713 cm−1 were attributed to the internal and external deformation mode of CaCO3 [41]. Besides the aforementioned bands, a feeble band NH vibration of protein was observed at 1635 cm−1 in the eggshell [33]. These observations proved again that the main component of eggshell was CaCO3. Compared with the eggshell and CaCO3 supports and Co3O4 catalyst, the infrared signatures of Co3O4/CaCO3 and Co3O4/eggshell catalysts displayed two more low-frequency stretching bands at 586 and 669 cm−1 (Fig. 2 ). A literature survey revealed that the Co-O stretching bonds (Co3+ Otc-O and Co2+ Otc-O) are located in this range [27], implying that Co3O4 was formed in these catalysts. The peak intensity ratio of ICo3+-O /ICo2+-O for Co3O4 was calculated to be 1.01 compared to 1.05 for Co3O4/eggshell-DP and 1.06 for Co3O4/CaCO3. The value was much higher than that of Co3O4/eggshell-IM (0.56) and Co3O4/eggshell-GR (0.79), indicating that the crystal structure of Co3O4 in Co3O4/eggshell-DP was more integrated. Thus, more abundant Co3O4 nanoparticles were formed in Co3O4/eggshell-DP. The IR results were consistent with the XRD analysis results. 3.1.3 BET analysis Typically, sample texture has an important influence on catalytic performance [42]. Therefore, the textural parameters of the resulting samples were compared. As listed in Table 1, pure eggshell and CaCO3 showed a small SBET of < 5 m2 g−1 and a Vtotal of 0.017 cm3 g−1, demonstrating the poorly-developed porous structure of these two samples. That is, they had the poor textural properties. Voids between particles caused porosity in these samples [33]. Compared with the support materials, loading Co3O4 onto the eggshell support did not change the textural properties of the Co3O4/eggshell-IM and Co3O4/eggshell-GR catalysts. This was because pores of the supports were covered or blocked by Co3O4 loading. While the SBET and Vtotal of Co3O4/eggshell-DP were increased to 14.1 m2 g−1 and 0.050 cm3 g−1. This was related to the formation of plentiful good-quality spherical Co3O4 nanoparticles in the Co3O4/eggshell-DP (will be presented shortly). The higher SBET and porous structure suggested that many active surface sites existed in the Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst, favorable for the deN2O reaction [43]. Table 1 also gave the actual Co3O4 contents of the Co3O4/eggshell catalysts, varying from 19.1 to 19.7 wt.%, which are close to the theoretical value (20 wt.%). 3.1.4 (HR)-TEM and HADDF-STEM analysis (HR)-TEM images of some typical samples are displayed in Fig. 3 . The TEM image of pure eggshell showed tiny holes, as shown in Fig. 3(a), confirming the presence of canals between the CaCO3 layer and cuticle layer for exchanging matter [44]. The TEM images of Co3O4/eggshell-IM and Co3O4/eggshell-GR revealed the presence of apparent aggregation of the ill-shaped Co3O4 nanoparticles (Fig. 3(b) and (c)). The Co3O4/eggshell-DP showed plentiful good-quality spherical Co3O4 nanoparticles distributed over the eggshell (Fig. 3(d)). At further magnifications (Fig. 3(d’)), the HR-TEM image of Co3O4/eggshell-DP displayed lattice spacings of 0.46 nm, 0.24 nm, and 0.26 nm, ascribed to the diffraction planes (111) and (311) of Co3O4 and (112) of CaCO3 [41,45], respectively. Moreover, the (311) plane of Co3O4 and (112) plane of CaCO3 cross-combined with each other. Thus, these observations confirmed the close incorporation between Co3O4 nanoparticles and CaCO3 in Co3O4/eggshell-DP and agreed well with the XRD and FT-IR results. HAADF-STEM and EDX elemental mapping were also obtained to investigate the elemental distribution in the Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst (Fig. 4 (a)-(i)). The data revealed that Co, O, and Ca element signals had similar shapes and locations and were homogeneously distributed, indicating that Co3O4 was uniformly distributed over the eggshell and was in close contact with the eggshell. Additionally, EDX elemental mapping showed the existence and dispersion of K, Na, and Mg elements in the Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst. 3.1.5 H2-TPR analysis The reduction performance of the samples and different Co species present in the samples were investigated by H2-TPR analysis. Fig. 5 displays the derived H2-TPR profiles for the resulting materials. For pure eggshell, a peak appeared at > 600 °C, related to the decomposition of CaCO3 into CO2 [41]. For the Co3O4 sample, two reduction peaks were observed with maxima at 323 °C (labeled as peak I) and 398 °C (labeled as peak II). Based on the literature data, PI-H2 and PII-H2 TPR peaks were attributed to the following processes: (i) reduction of Co3+ to Co2+, (ii) reduction of Co2+ to Co; viz. Co3+→Co2+→Co0 [45]. These H2-TPR profiles of Co3O4/eggshell catalysts revealed these two peaks. The PI-H2 peak obtained maxima at 354 °C, 280 °C, and 295 °C for Co3O4/eggshell-GR, Co3O4/eggshell-IM, and Co3O4/eggshell-DP, respectively. The PII-H2 peak was centered at 407 °C, 405 °C, and 364 °C for these catalysts. Along with the above-mentioned peaks, Co3O4/eggshell-GR and Co3O4/eggshell-IM generated a PIII-H2 TPR peak at 545 °C and 553 °C representing the reduction of Co2+ had an interaction with eggshell. Additionally, a PIV-H2 TPR peak was observed at > 600 °C in Co3O4/eggshell-GR and Co3O4/eggshell-IM, which was due to the decomposition of CaCO3 into CO2. In contrast, for Co3O4/eggshell-DP, a reduction peak was observed at > 500 °C (reduction of Co2+ had an interaction with eggshell and decomposition of CaCO3 into CO2). The decomposition peaks of CaCO3 for the investigated Co3O4/eggshell catalysts were initiated at lower temperatures compared to eggshell alone in all cases, and the temperature of Co3O4/eggshell-DP transferred to a much lower temperature. The Mars-van Krevelen redox mechanism was considered to be the foundational basis explaining the strong interaction between Co3O4 and CaCO3 [46]; the Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst showed the lowest decomposition temperature for CaCO3. These findings showed that Co3O4/eggshell-DP exhibited higher reducibility with a lower reduction temperature and stronger interaction between Co3O4 and CaCO3 compared with other samples. The actual H2 uptake amounts of the samples were determined based on the quantification results of the H2-TPR experiment (Table 2 ). The actual H2 uptake amounts of PI-H2 in these samples were as follows: Co3O4 (4.17 mmol·g−1) ≈ Co3O4/eggshell-DP (4.16 mmol·g−1) > Co3O4/eggshell-GR (1.18 mmol·g−1) > Co3O4/eggshell-IM (1.03 mmol·g−1). This order indicated that Co3O4/eggshell-DP possessed significant higher number of Co3+ species. Also, the actual PI-H2 uptake amount and PII-H2 uptake amount in these catalysts were compared. The ratio of the H2 uptake amount of PI to that of PII over Co3O4 was 0.33, which was equal to the theoretical value [47]. However, the ratio of H2 uptake amount of PI to that of PII over Co3O4/eggshell samples followed the following sequence: Co3O4/eggshell-DP (0.38) > Co3O4/eggshell-IM (0.25) > Co3O4/eggshell-DP (0.22). These data indicated that the crystal structure of Co3O4 had higher integration, resulting in the formation of a higher number of Co3O4 nanoparticles in Co3O4/eggshell-DP. The results of the H2-TPR analysis were consistent with the results of XRD, FT-IR, and (HR)-TEM analysis. 3.1.6 XPS analysis Fig. 6 shows the results of XPS analyses of Co3O4 and Co3O4/eggshell samples to investigate the effects of surface elemental compositions and valence states on activity. The general XPS survey spectra (Fig. S3) of all Co3O4/eggshell samples indicated the presence of Ca, O, Co along with other atoms on the surface, which was consistent with the element mapping results (Fig. 4). The Co 2p spectrum of Co3O4 sample (Fig. 6(A)) contained Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 peaks at binding energy (BE) 779.7 and 794.6 eV, along with Co2+ satellite peaks at 788.4 and 803.3 eV [48]. The same components were observed for the Co3O4/eggshell samples, whereas the Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 peaks appeared at relatively lower BE values. This was probably due to the fact that Ca, Na, and Mg in the Co3O4/eggshell played a key role in the weakening of the Co-O bond, similar to that of K in the K/Co3O4 catalyst [17]. Considering that the peak fittings of Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 components gave the same surface species [49], this study was solely focused on the analysis of the Co 2p3/2 component. For Co3O4, the Co 2p3/2 component could be fitted into two peaks at BE values of 779.6 and 781.2 eV, corresponding to Co3+ and Co2+ species [45]. The deconvolution of the XPS spectra of Co3O4/eggshell catalysts showed similar results. Based on previous studies, the Co3+ species were used for determining the catalytic activity of Co3O4-based catalysts in deN2O [47]. Table 3 shows the molar ratio of Co3+/Co2+ in these samples. The XPS data showed that the Co3+/Co2+molar ratio of Co3O4/eggshell-DP had the highest value (1.05) compared to those of Co3O4 (1.01), Co3O4/eggshell-GR (0.95), and Co3O4/eggshell-IM (0.93). The oxygen vacancy also plays an important role in improving the catalytic activity of Co3O4-based catalysts in deN2O reactions [48]. The results of O 1s XPS analysis showed that the O 1s spectra in Fig. 6(B) exhibited two peaks at BE values of ∼529 and 531 eV, which were characteristic of lattice oxygen (OL) and surface adsorbed oxygen (OS), respectively. The removal of lattice oxygen results in the production of oxygen vacancies; consequently, the number of lattice oxygen species reflects the content of oxygen vacancies [50]. As shown in Table 3, the OS/(OS+OL) showed the following trend: Co3O4/eggshell-DP (0.37) < Co3O4/eggshell-IM (0.78) < Co3O4/eggshell-GR (0.89), indicating the presence of a relatively higher number of oxygen vacancies in the Co3O4/eggshell-DP. Therefore, based on these XPS analyses, methods of synthesis of Co3O4/eggshell samples had a significant impact on the content of surface Co3+ species and oxygen vacancies. The Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst possessed the highest amount of surface Co3+ species and oxygen vacancies, which, theoretically, should have exhibited the best catalytic activity in catalytic deN2O. As further proof, EPR tests of the Co3O4/eggshell catalysts were carried out. From Fig. 7 , a strong EPR signal was observed at g = 2.004, which corresponded to the oxygen vacancies [8]. The peak intensity for the Co3O4/eggshell catalysts showed the following trend: Co3O4/eggshell-GR < Co3O4/eggshell-IM < Co3O4/eggshell-DP. The higher intensity of EPR signal unambiguously demonstrated that more oxygen vacancies existed in the Co3O4/eggshell-DP sample. 3.1.7 CO2-TPD analysis Previous studies have shown that the surface basicity of the catalyst is significant for catalytic deN2O, as it donates electrons to N2O molecules [51]. Accordingly, the type, number, and strength of surface basicity on the catalyst were assessed by performing CO2-TPD analysis (Fig. 8 ). In the case of Co3O4, two CO2 desorption peaks appeared in the temperature range from 50 °C to 550 °C. The desorption peak < 250 °C was due to the weak basic sites, while the desorbed peak > 250 °C was due to the strong basic sites [51]. However, the CO2-TPD profiles changed significantly in the Co3O4/eggshell catalyst. No obvious signal was measured for Co3O4/eggshell-GR, while one desorption peak at about 450 °C was measured for Co3O4/eggshell-IM and Co3O4/eggshell-DP. This peak could be due to the presence of strong basic sites. The temperatures required for the desorption of synthesized Co3O4/eggshell-IM and Co3O4/eggshell-DP were considerably higher than the other prepared samples. Co3O4/eggshell-DP had a larger CO2 desorption area compared with other samples. In the CO2-TPD experiment, the temperature of the desorption peak was related to the base strength, and the area of the desorption peak was associated with the number of basic sites [52]. Thus, the Co3O4/eggshell-DP sample had stronger surface basicity and more basic sites. The number of different types of basic sites and total basic sites on the surfaces of the samples were also calculated and listed in Table 4 . The total basic sites of the samples were in the following order: Co3O4/eggshell-DP > Co3O4/eggshell-IM > Co3O4 > Co3O4/eggshell-GR. This research group has previously reported such a phenomenon using Co3O4/g-C3N4, Co3O4/ZrO2, and NCo3O4 catalysts for catalytic deN2O [8,26,27]. 3.1.8 Conductivity tests It has been documented that the deN2O activities of Co3O4-based catalysts are related to their electrical conductivities. The higher the conductivity, the more favor is the electron transfer, favoring N2O adsorption and decomposition [27,53]. Table 3 summarizes the conductivities of all the catalysts. The conductivity values of the catalysts in sequence followed Co3O4/eggshell-DP > Co3O4/eggshell-GR > Co3O4/eggshell-IM > Co3O4. The conductivity value of the Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst reached 25.7 × 10−5 Ω−1 cm−1. The big electrical conductivity difference between Co3O4/eggshell-DP and other catalysts suggested that donating electrons from the catalyst surface to N2O molecules would be easier, therefore promoting deN2O. These results consist with CO2-TPD. 3.2 deN2O activity 3.2.1 For the feed gas of 1000 ppm N2O/Ar N2O conversion as a function of reaction temperature for the prepared samples in an inert gas is shown in Fig. 9 . The pure eggshell exhibited only minimal catalytic activity in the investigated temperature range; The N2O conversion started at approximately 420 °C. At 440 °C, an N2O conversion of 3% was obtained over the sample. After the eggshell was loaded with an appropriate amount of Co3O4, the catalytic performance of all Co3O4/eggshell catalysts improved. At 440 °C, the N2O conversion of 10%, 20%, and 100% were obtained over Co3O4/eggshell-GR, Co3O4/eggshell-IM, and Co3O4/eggshell-DP, respectively. The results clearly indicated that catalytic deN2O over Co3O4/eggshell-DP was much more efficient than Co3O4/eggshell-IM and Co3O4/eggshell-GR. Notably, the Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst showed higher activity than Co3O4. The complete conversion temperature (T100) of Co3O4/eggshell-DP was 400 °C, lower than the T100 of Co3O4 (420 °C). The specific activity, i.e., the converted volume of N2O based on the mass of the catalyst and the reaction time, was calculated to prove the superiority of eggshell as support used for deN2O. The specific activity of Co3O4/eggshell-DP at 400 °C was calculated to be 0.11 μmol s−1 g−1 for, 7.3 times that of the Co3O4 catalyst (inset of Fig. 9). The deN2O catalytic performance of Co3O4/eggshell-DP was compared with those of the supported Co3O4-based catalysts utilized by other research groups (see Table S1) [54]. Though it is difficult to accurately compare the catalytic performance of these catalysts under different conditions, it can be safely concluded the Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst exhibited better activity and higher specific activity than those previously. Therefore, cheap eggshells can achieve results comparable to other considerably more expensive supports. The intrinsic catalytic ability of samples can also be reflected by comparing the apparent activation energy (Ea) values, where the lower activation energy of the sample suggests superior activity [45]. Early studies have preliminarily shown that catalytic deN2O is a first-order reaction [24,26]. As shown in Fig. 10 and Table S2, when the deN2O reaction was kept to the dynamic region (N2O conversion < 15%), the slope of the Arrhenius curve was used for evaluating the Ea. The apparent Ea values were calculated based on the slopes of the Arrhenius plots. The apparent Ea of Co3O4/eggshell-DP was 60.5 kJ mol−1, lower than that of Co3O4 (89.4 kJ mol−1), and even lower than that of some reported supported Co3O4-based catalysts [26,27]. 3.2.2 For the feed gas of 1000 ppm N2O/Ar with various compositions The anti-poisoning properties of catalysts are critical for practical applications [55]. H2O, O2, and NO are normally present in N2O-containing gas streams actually emitted [25]. Therefore, the effects of these components in the reactant feed on N2O conversion were studied in the presence of Co3O4/eggshell-DP and Co3O4 samples. Fig. 11 shows the results of deN2O under the model atmosphere (1000 ppm N2O diluted in Ar) and feed gas containing H2O (3.3 vol.%), O2 (3 vol.%), and/or NO (200 ppm). In the case of Co3O4, an additional component in the reactant feed shifted the activity profiles to higher temperatures. The compositions 1000 ppm N2O+3.3 vol.% H2O, 1000 ppm N2O+3 vol.% O2, and 1000 ppm N2O+200 ppm NO had T50 values were 380, 375, and 405 °C, respectively. In contrast to a component, the inhibiting effects of the two compositions in the reactant feed were much stronger. The activity of the examined Co3O4 catalyst decreased in the presence of 1000 ppm N2O+3 vol.% O2+3.3 vol.% H2O and 1000 ppm N2O+3 vol.% O2+200 ppm NO, which in turn increased T100 to about 412 and 427 °C. Compared with Co3O4, the catalytic activity of the Co3O4/eggshell-DP dropped under H2O, O2 and/or NO-containing atmosphere. However, the activity patterns of Co3O4/eggshell-DP were slightly shifted towards higher temperatures. Thus, the Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst exhibited rich anti-poisoning properties. 3.3 deN2O stability The thermal stability of Co3O4 and Co3O4/eggshell-DP was investigated at 400 °C with time on stream, and the results are exhibited in Fig. 12 . In the beginning, N2O conversion was controlled at 100% with a reaction temperature (T100= 400 °C). The N2O conversion could be kept at 100% for 40 h with the Co3O4/eggshell-DP. However, the N2O conversion of Co3O4 could only be maintained at 100% for about 15 h. After that, N2O conversion decreased to 80% in 40 h. The results demonstrated that the Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst displayed excellent long-term thermal stability. The stability and anti-poisoning properties of Co3O4/eggshell-DP were also studied in this study through a step-change experiment in which the feed composition was switched periodically between 1000 ppm N2O in Ar, N2O/Ar + 3.3 vol.% H2O, 200 ppm NO, N2O/Ar + 3.3 vol.% H2O + 200 ppm NO, and 3 vol.% O2. The results of this experiment (Fig. 13 ) revealed that the Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst regenerated its initial activity after being exposed to H2O/NO/O2, implying that it had a completely reversible character of H2O/NO/O2 poisoning. These findings highlight the outstanding stability and anti-poisoning property of the Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst towards deN2O. 3.4 Discussion The catalytic deN2O over Co3O4 spinel has been reported to follow different redox mechanisms. Some authors propose that the active site is Co2+, which activates N2O molecules, forming Co3+-O− via electron transfer [Eq.(II)]. Next, the Co3+-O− species diffuse and recombine into O2. Meanwhile, Co2+ is regenerated, and the catalytic cycle is completed [Eq.(III)] [17]. Others describe the active site as Co3+. When Eq.(II) is finished, Co3+-O− species can directly react with N2O molecules to generate O2, N2, and Co2+ [Eq.(IV)], closing the catalytic cycle [47]. The active site has also been reported to be oxygen vacancies, which adsorb N2O and forms Co3+-O− [Eq.(V)], The Co3+-O−can react with each other to generate oxygen vacancies, completing the catalytic cycle [Eq.(VI)] [56]. Though a consensus for the deN2O reaction mechanism over the Co3O4 spinel catalyst has still not been reached, it is accepted that relative amounts of Co2+, Co3+, and oxygen vacancies, Co-O bond strength, and Co2+ ↔ Co3+ redox potential control the whole reaction. (II) Co2+ + N2O →Co3+-O− + N2 (III) 2Co3+-O− → O2 + 2Co2+ (IV) Co3+-O− + N2O → Co2+ + N2 + O2 (V) Co2+-Ovac + N2O → Co3+-O− + N2 (VI) 2Co3+-O− → 2Co2+-Ovac + O2 XRD and FT-IR characterization indicated that the main component of eggshell was CaCO3. XRD, FT-IR, XPS, and H2-TPR analyses revealed the existence of Co3O4 spinel in all the examined Co3O4/eggshell catalysts. However, the preparation methods significantly influenced on the crystal structure of Co3O4. The Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst owned the more integrated crystal structure of Co3O4 and more abundant Co3O4 nanoparticles had close incorporation with eggshell support. The BET analyses indicated that the preparation methods were related to the SBET and Vtotal of Co3O4/eggshell catalysts. Pure eggshell showed a small SBET and Vtotal . Loading Co3O4 onto the eggshell support did not change obviously the SBET and Vtotal of the Co3O4/eggshell-IM and Co3O4/eggshell-GR catalysts. Whereas, the SBET and Vtotal of Co3O4/eggshell-DP obviously increased, which was conducive to more accessible active sites. The H2-TPR results revealed a good correlation between the redox property of Co3O4 and the preparation methods of the Co3O4/eggshell catalyst. The Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst displayed excellent redox ability. The XPS and EPR data revealed that preparation methods greatly affected the content of surface Co3+ species and oxygen vacancies of Co3O4/eggshell catalysts. The Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst possessed the comparatively highest surface Co3+ species and oxygen vacancies. Further, the CO2-TPD analysis showed that surface basicity and basic sites were significantly related to the preparation methods of Co3O4/eggshell catalysts. The Co3O4/eggshell-DP sample showed much stronger surface basicity and more basic sites than others. Conductivity tests suggested that a big electrical conductivity difference existed between Co3O4/eggshell-DP and other catalysts, and Co3O4/eggshell-DP would be easier to donate electrons. Consequently, these properties resulted in Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst having a lower Ea for deN2O, therefore exhibiting a superior activity. Based on the mechanism of deN2O over cobalt-based spinels, previous studies have indicated the presence of competitive adsorption of N2O and impurity gasses such as H2O, NO, and O2 on the catalyst surface, hindering the redox cycle of Co2+↔Co3+ over the catalyst [17,47,56]. The experimental results confirmed a strong interaction between Co3O4 and CaCO3 in the Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst. The reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ was much easier for the Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst than for Co3O4. In other words, the strong interaction endued the Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst a relatively weak Co-O bond that was favorable for the regeneration of the redox cycle of Co2+↔Co3+. Therefore, Co3O4/eggshell-DP exhibited higher catalytic activity and anti-poisoning properties for deN2O than the Co3O4 catalyst. At present, there are many reports that structured (e.g. monoliths) cobalt spinel catalysts are tested as state-of the art deN2O catalysts at the industrial scale, especially in a nitric acid pilot plant [57–59]. In our work, we found that Co3O4/eggshell-DP could be used as a high-performance catalyst for deN2O. Thus, further studies are going in our research group for transforming the Co3O4/eggshell-DP system into the structured catalysts. Their deN2O performance is examined in model and real conditions. 4 Conclusions This study prepared Co3O4/eggshell-GR, Co3O4/eggshell-IM, and Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalysts by grinding, impregnation, and deposition-precipitation methods for catalytic deN2O. The Co3O4/eggshell-DP demonstrated a specific activity 7.3 times higher than pure Co3O4 at 400 °C, superior stability during the longevity test, and excellent tolerance towards NO, O2, and/or H2O. Experimental results proved that the boosted catalytic performance of Co3O4/eggshell-DP was contributed to the unique structure of eggshell and the close incorporation between CaCO3 and Co3O4, combined abundant Co3O4 nanoparticles, higher Co3+ species, excellent redox performance, abundant surface basic sites, and a larger number of oxygen vacancies. The findings of this study will guide the use of Co3O4 nanoparticles decorated eggshell catalysts for the application of deN2O and other related reactions, achieve waste reuse, and reduce environmental pollution. coredata.dc:description: Co3O4 shows excellent catalytic activity for N2O decomposition, in which it is urgently needed to develop novel efficient catalysts/supports with cheap and environmentally-friendly properties. Herein, Co3O4 nanoparticles decorated eggshell catalysts (Co3O4/eggshell-GR, Co3O4/eggshell-IM, and Co3O4/eggshell-DP) were prepared using simple grinding, impregnation, and deposition-precipitation methods, where waste eggshells were used as an effective support and reaction-promoter. The results indicated that the preparation methods significantly influenced the catalytic activity of Co3O4/eggshell catalysts; the highest activity was obtained over the Co3O4/eggshell-DP. The activity of Co3O4/eggshell-DP was comparable to that of pure Co3O4. More importantly, its specific activity was about 7.3 times that of Co3O4 at 400 °C. The examined Co3O4/eggshell-DP also displayed outstanding stability and anti-poisoning property in NO, O2, and/or H2O-containing atmospheres. It was also verified that the excellent activity of Co3O4/eggshell-DP correlated with the unique structure of the eggshell and the close incorporation between CaCO3 and Co3O4. The Co3O4/eggshell-DP catalyst owned abundant Co3O4 nanoparticles, more Co3+ species, and excellent redox performance, promoting the conversion of N2O at a lower temperature. The presence of abundant surface basic sites and a larger amount of oxygen vacancies also facilitated the catalytic efficiency of Co3O4/eggshell-DP.
coredata.dc:title: Waste eggshell to valuable Co3O4/eggshell material as an efficient catalyst for catalytic decomposition of N2O under simulated real tail gases
